content.user_title: Track AI Work Across Sessions with GitHub Issues
content.value_statement: Context loss from session boundaries makes AI work difficult to sustain. This skill transforms GitHub Issues into permanent memory for AI agents, surviving compaction and enabling true multi-session collaboration with complete traceability.
actual_capabilities: Create and manage DEV, TEST, and REVIEW threads as GitHub Issues
Post checkpoints and state snapshots to issue threads
Recover work after context compaction by reading issue history
Coordinate multiple agents through wave and epic structures
Integrate with SERENA MCP for project-level memory and large documents
Enforce phase-gated workflow with strict order: DEV â†’ TEST â†’ REVIEW
limitations: Requires GitHub CLI (gh) authentication for operations
SERENA MCP must be installed separately for memory bank features
Does not execute code or run tests directly
Does not modify files outside the project directory

use_cases.target_user: AI developers working on complex features
use_cases.title: Multi-Session Feature Development
use_cases.description: Work on features across multiple sessions without losing context. Checkpoints preserve state for recovery.

use_cases.title: Multi-Agent Coordination
use_cases.description: Coordinate parallel agent work with wave structures, scope declarations, and merge coordination protocols.

use_cases.title: Project Memory and Documentation
use_cases.description: Store project context, technical decisions, and large documents using SERENA MCP integration.

prompt_templates.title: Start New Feature
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a DEV thread for implementing [feature]. Use the github-elements-tracking skill. Include required skills, thread type (dev), and scope declaration.

prompt_templates.title: Post Checkpoint
prompt_templates.prompt: Post a checkpoint to issue #[number] documenting: completed tasks, in-progress work, files changed, commits made, and next action.

prompt_templates.title: Recover After Compaction
prompt_templates.prompt: Find my assigned issues with gh issue list --assignee @me --label in-progress. Read the last checkpoint from the issue thread to understand current state.

prompt_templates.title: Transition Phase
prompt_templates.prompt: Close the current DEV thread and create a TEST thread. Include: phase:test label, test scope declaration, and reference to the completed DEV work.

output_examples.input: Post a checkpoint for the JWT authentication feature I'm working on
output: Implement blacklist check in validation middleware

best_practices: Post checkpoints at meaningful state changes, not time intervals
Always declare scope (files to modify) before starting work
Use the state snapshot format for recoverability
Follow strict phase order: DEV â†’ TEST â†’ REVIEW (never skip)
anti_patterns: Working without checkpoints (context will be lost)
Skipping scope declaration (leads to file conflicts)
Self-approval (PR author cannot be sole tester/reviewer)
Demoting REVIEW failures to TEST instead of DEV

faq.question: What tools are required for this skill?
faq.answer: GitHub CLI (gh) with authenticated login is required. SERENA MCP is optional but recommended for large documents.

faq.question: What happens during context compaction?
faq.answer: All work is preserved in GitHub issue threads. New sessions recover by reading the last checkpoint from the issue thread.

faq.question: Can multiple agents work on the same feature?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes multi-instance coordination protocols with scope declarations, locks, and broadcast mechanisms.

faq.question: How does SERENA MCP integration work?
faq.answer: SERENA stores large documents and project-level context. The skill references SERENA memory files when GitHub limits are exceeded.

faq.question: What is the circular phase order?
faq.answer: Features flow through DEV (write code) â†’ TEST (run tests) â†’ REVIEW (evaluate). Failures demote back to DEV, never to TEST.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides protocols and documentation. Actual code changes are done by other tools following the documented workflows.
